thread.title: What do Newcastle and Sunderland results tell us about the referendum vote so far?
thread.title_full: What do Newcastle and Sunderland results tell us about the referendum vote so far?

author: Will Metcalfe
title: What do Newcastle and Sunderland results tell us about the referendum vote so far?
text:
What do Newcastle and Sunderland results tell us about the referendum vote so far? 01:01, 24 Jun 2016 More than two thirds of voters in Newcastle turned out but the Remain majority was much lower than predicted Shares The video will start in 8 s Cancel Click to play Tap to play The Live Event you are trying to watch is either unavailable or has not started Please refresh this page in your browser to reload this live event video 
The campaign for Britain to leave the EU appears to have been bolstered following results from Tyne and Wear - the first two to be declared on mainland Britain. 
While experts predicted a double figure victory for Remain in Newcastle, the result came down to just 1807 for the pro-EU campaign – which many think could lead to stronger support nationally. 
Late on Thursday Pat Ritchie, chief executive of Newcastle City Council, declared the result with 65,404 people backing Remain but 63,598 people voting to Leave. 
A procession of high profile Remain campaigners had been parachuted in to the North East including Lord Mandelson, Alistair Darling and Alan Johnson as the campaign continued. 
And Newcastle had been expected to show stronger support for the EU due to a large student population. 
But as the count was carried out Brexiteers were spotted in tears with many refusing to speak about their referendum campaign. 
Despite the tight result on Tyneside, the Leave campaign took an unexpected advantage on Wearside. 
Shortly after the Newcastle result Sunderland revealed more than 60% of votes cast were in favour of the Leave campaign which pulled in 82,394 votes compared to the 51,930 for Remain. 
On Wearside the support for Brexit could be seen in this May’s local elections. 
Though UKIP failed to secure a seat on Sunderland City Council the party came second in nine of the 12 seats contested in the council elections in May which suggests an underlying anti-EU sentiment. VIEW GALLERY 
However, Wearside’s economy is bolstered by the Nissan car plant in Washington which employs some 6,700 and the Japanese firm had hinted it could consider leaving if Britain votes to leave the EU. 
The pound had risen following early polls which suggested a victory for the Remain campaign but after the first two North East results it fell from 1.49 against the dollar to 1.43 as faith in a victory for Remain were immediately dented. 
The turnout across Britain could be crucial. In Newcastle, it was 67.7% and in Sunderland it was 64.9%. For the last General Election, turnout was 60.3% in Newcastle and 57,2% in Sunderland - a fair jump in both cities. 
With the Newcastle vote tighter than expected and the Sunderland Leave win bigger than expected - hopes of those who want to leave the EU have had an early boost. More on the EU Referendum
